「The Method of Boiling Glue: Take deer antlers in any quantity. First, place them in a clay pot filled with water and soak for three days, then drain. Wash them with sand from the river until their yellow color appears.

Next, take a piece of lead about two *cùn* long, rinse with fresh river water, and soak in the pot for three days. Use a large covered clay bowl. Mix *guàn* clay (a type of waterproofing mud) with aged *bì* soil (a type of earth) to form a paste to seal the bowl. According to the size of the bowl, fashion a stopper (*áo*).

Pour the water from the second soaking into the bowl, then add the deer antlers and boil. Continuously heat water in an iron pot and pour it before the stopper. If the water in the bowl decreases by one *cùn*, replenish it by one *cùn*—never add cold water, only pure *lì* charcoal. For three days and nights, the fire must never cease; boil until the antlers are fully softened. On the fourth day at dawn, drain the liquid and, while still hot, scrape off the skin to obtain deer antler glue (*lùjiǎo shuāng*).

The remaining broth in the bowl must be simmered until it thickens to one-tenth of its original volume. Pour it through a bamboo tube and hang it in a cold, shaded place—it will solidify by the next morning. Break open the bamboo tube, shape the residue into lead cakes (*qiān bǐngzǐ*), and store them.

Another Method of Boiling Glue: Deer antlers—whether freshly dead or not, in any quantity, about three *cùn* in length—should be cut and the outer skin removed. Soak the antler shavings in river water for seven days, changing the water daily until the antlers are thoroughly washed. Boil them in a pot. For every five *jīn* of antlers, use half a *jīn* of *sāngbái* bark (mulberry bark), one *jīn* of *chùshízi* (paper mulberry fruit), two *liǎng* of imported *liúhuáng* (sulfur), and two *liǎng* of *zhūshā* (cinnabar). Boil them together. When the water is exhausted, add more broth. By the time of one *fú* (a period of two hours), the antlers will naturally soften. If the fire is not allowed to stop and they remain unsoftened, boil them again for one *fú*. Once softened, cool them and remove the antlers, then hang them in a well-ventilated place to dry. Filter the deer antler broth to remove all the herbs, then simmer it slowly over low heat to obtain glue (*jiāo*).

The Method of Pill-making: For each *jīn* of medicine, use one *jīn* of honey as a binder, mixed with flour paste. For every four *liǎng* of powdered medicine, use four *liǎng* of the drug and one *liǎng* of rice flour.

chunks.original_text: 用朱砂一两半，细末。 汞一两，同研极相着。 用绵子曩，悬胎石灰汁，并羌花末一两，同煮一伏时。 取去，蜜调羌花、草乌、天南星、嫩地榆叶，如指厚。 又用白友、白蔽，用椒末？ 以鸡子清调，又包一重。 入合，用白虎末铺盖，用油调蚌粉固缝，入瓦瓷中，养火七日。 初一日二日，火一两。 至三日四日，火四两。 五日六日，火六两。 七日一斤，火毁一日，候冷取出，是为第一转。 第二转 用汞二两，依前结砂煮药，同前煮了，入合内，养二七日。 一日二日，火一两。 三日四日，火四两。

chunks.original_text: 五日六日，火六两。 七日八日，火八两。 九日十日，火十两。 十一日十二日，火十二两。 十三十四日，火三十两。 第三转 汞二两，同前结砂子煮，又封固入火养三七日。 初一日初二日，火一两。 三日四日，火四两。 五日六日，火六两。 七日八日，火八两。 九日十日，火十两。 十一十二日，火十二两。 十三十四日，火三十两，养至日足。 第四转 取元砂子，秤看折多少，秤汞等分，依前法煮结，入火养三七日，取出。 用新砂合子一个，用砂子铺盖光明砂十两在内，用蜜调紫□□□□□□末贴合子，身外用鸡子清，调细墨贴身，又用前药封白虎，铺盖前药，为固济砂禁法也。 火合子内铺盖了，用油调蚌粉固缝，入火缸内，用三斤火，养四十九日足。 第五转 取明窗尘五两，乃纳朱砂也。 依前朱砂法铺盖了，用硫黄五两，七日取出，硫可制汞。 第六转 取五两药，铺盖雌黄，封固，养七日，制汞成庚。 第七转 取六转丹砂末，铺盖雄黄，封固，依前养七七日，可点铁成庚。 第八转 取七转丹砂末，楮汁丸如粟米大，每一粒水吞下，可延年益寿，与天地同也。 第九转 取七转丹砂，铺盖砒十两，养七日，可点五金，皆成至宝。 太上圣祖金丹秘诀 修炼金丹变化金石 太上圣祖金硫匮头，变化金宝，滋养无穷之法。 说三品金丹，第一品金丹，服之飞升金阙，名曰天仙。 第二品还丹，服之住世长年。 第三品神丹，变化五金八石，立成大宝，济世利身名日人仙。 得此术者名曰王公。 然不可传於下士，受之人并授之人，大殃，药亦不成。 可传授者，必须济人利物，所用有节。 枉费至药，永为下鬼。 得法遇人不传。 名隐天宝。 传得人者，同志可也。 若传非人，名曰泄天机。 此皆不可，亦招阴累。 修炼之士，宜慎焉。 修炼秘诀 用生麸金一两二钱，舶上硫黄二两。 右将金镕成汁，铸成锭子，判研成末，研极细。 取金末七钱，加硫二钱，同研如粉缅。 用小磁合一个，可盛得药尽者。 先将合子，以生姜磨墨涂三次。 炙乾，将金硫入合，以匙捺半实，用余金末半两，盖头令实。 上用醋墨纸盖七重，上用白矾末盖头，与合口平，赤石脂固封。 外以针砂磁石碾未，鸡子清调为膏，固济白合子了。 又用外匮一个，以伏火盐泥末，栽小合子在内，外匮合子内白合上面末，只可厚一指。 又将外匮合子，以赤石脂固口缝了，盐泥固济。 日乾，入灰缸内，养火三两，火养三日。 六两，火养六日。 如灰烬，即换去泥，开外匮取出小白合子，亦去却药皮，并口缝摩，取出白矾末，并吹去黑纸灰，揩拭合子四方令诤。 后用快刀取金硫，一如蜜陀僧色。 秤时依旧，一两四钱。 又将金硫入乳钵内研，秤出半两金硫盖头，将九钱金硫末，又将生硫二钱，准前法入合，将余半两盖头，依前次序，入外匮固济，再入灰池，其法火候依前分两日数。 开合研细，秤时依旧一两六钱，其硫已大段伏火。 又用金硫末再研，入生硫二钱入合，以余金硫六钱盖头，依前固济，准前火候法温养日足。 但加绝硫二两，尽为度。 如合小换大合，依法养，共三两二钱，伏火圣祖匮。 次用养宝法 右将小块朱砂，如豆大者。 先以无油跳子一个，将匮末在跳内，用朱砂一两，慢火炒紫色止。

Five days and six days, use six *liǎng* of fire.
Seven days and eight days, use eight *liǎng* of fire.
Nine days and ten days, use ten *liǎng* of fire.
Eleven days and twelve days, use twelve *liǎng* of fire.
Thirteen and fourteen days, use thirty *liǎng* of fire.

**Third Transformation:** Use two *liǎng* of Mercury, following the prior method of binding with Cinnabar and boiling, then sealing and nurturing with fire for another three sevens of days.
On the first and second days, use one *liǎng* of fire.
From the third to the fourth days, use four *liǎng* of fire.
On the fifth and six days, use six *liǎng* of fire.
Seven days and eight days, use eight *liǎng* of fire.
Nine days and ten days, use ten *liǎng* of fire.
Eleven and twelve days, use twelve *liǎng* of fire.
Thirteen and fourteen days, use thirty *liǎng* of fire, nurturing until completion.

**Fourth Transformation:** Take the original Cinnabar, weigh its quantity, and measure an equal amount of Mercury. Following the previous method, boil and bind, then place in fire to nurture for three sevens of days, and remove.

Take a new Cinnabar container, lay ten *liǎng* of bright Cinnabar (*guāngmíng shā*) inside, and seal the container with honey-mixed [illegible] powder. On the exterior, use egg white to mix with fine ink and seal the body. Then, use the prior medicine to seal the White Tiger [medicine], covering it with the prior medicine—this is the method of securing the Cinnabar.

Place the sealed container inside, mix shell powder with oil to seal the seams, and place it in a fire pot with three *jīn* of fire. Nurture for forty-nine days to completion.

**Fifth Transformation:** Take five *liǎng* of *míngchuāng chén* (window dust), which is the refined Cinnabar. Following the prior method of layering Cinnabar, add five *liǎng* of sulfur, and after seven days, remove—sulfur can now subdue Mercury.

**Sixth Transformation:** Take five *liǎng* of the medicine, layer with Orpiment (*qīhuáng*), seal, and nurture for seven days to subdue Mercury into *gēng* (a refined state).

**Seventh Transformation:** Take the powdered Cinnabar from the sixth transformation, layer with Realgar (*xiónghuáng*), seal, and nurture for seven sevens of days—this can transmute iron into *gēng*.

**Eighth Transformation:** Take the powdered Cinnabar from the seventh transformation, form pills with *chǔ* (ramie) juice the size of millet grains. Each pill, swallowed with water, can prolong life and align one with the Dao of Heaven and Earth.

**Ninth Transformation:** Take the Cinnabar from the seventh transformation, layer with ten *liǎng* of arsenic (*pí*), and nurture for seven days—this can transmute the five metals into supreme treasures.

---
**The Supreme Ancestor’s Secret Prescription for Golden Elixir**
**Refining the Golden Elixir to Transform Metals and Stones**
The Supreme Ancestor’s Golden Sulfur Secret—transforming metals into treasures, nourishing endlessly.

It speaks of the Three Grades of Golden Elixir:
The First Grade of Golden Elixir—when taken, ascends to the Golden Palace of Heaven, named *Tiānxiān* (Celestial Immortal).
The Second Grade of Returning Elixir—when taken, grants longevity in this world.
The Third Grade of Spirit Elixir—transforms the five metals and eight stones into great treasures, benefiting the world and the self, named *Rénxiān* (Human Immortal).

Those who possess this art are called *Wánggōng* (Kings and Dukes).
Yet it must not be transmitted to the unworthy. Both the recipient and the transmitter will suffer great misfortune, and the medicine will fail.
Only those who benefit others and act with restraint may be taught.
Wasting such precious medicine will bring eternal damnation as a lowly ghost.
If one obtains the method but does not transmit it to the worthy, it is called *Yǐn Tiānbǎo* (Hidden Heavenly Treasure).
If transmitted to the unworthy, it is called *Xiè Tiānjī* (Leaking Heaven’s Secrets).
These are all forbidden, and they invite karmic retribution.
Practitioners must be cautious.

---
**Secret Prescription for Refining**
Take one *liǎng* and two *qián* of live *fǔjīn* (gold), and two *liǎng* of imported sulfur.
First, melt the gold into a liquid, cast it into ingots, grind into powder, and refine it to the finest consistency.
Take seven *qián* of gold powder, add two *qián* of sulfur, and grind together into a powder as fine as *mǐnyàn* (Indian myrobalan).

Take a small magnetic container that can hold all the medicine.
First, rub the container with ginger-ground ink three times, dry it, then place the gold-sulfur mixture inside, filling it halfway with a spoon. Use the remaining half-*liǎng* of gold powder to cover the top, sealing it tightly.
Cover with seven layers of vinegar-inked paper, then cover the top with white alum powder, level with the container’s rim, and seal with red stone pitch (*chìshízhī*).
Externally, grind magnetite and lodestone into powder, mix with egg white into a paste, and seal the white container securely.
Take another outer container, fill it with powdered *fúhuǒ yán* (buried salt), and place the small container inside. The space between the outer and inner containers should be no thicker than a finger.
Seal the outer container’s rim with red stone pitch and secure it with salt powder. Once dry, place it in an ash pot and nurture with three *liǎng* of fire for three days.
With six *liǎng* of fire, nurture for six days.
When reduced to ash, remove the outer container’s salt seal, open it, and take out the small white container. Also remove the medicine’s outer layer and the rim seal, blow away the black paper ash, and wipe the container clean on all sides.

Then, with a sharp knife, scrape the gold-sulfur mixture—it should resemble the color of *mìtuó sēng* (a Buddhist monk’s robe).
Weigh it as before: one *liǎng* and four *qián*.
Grind the gold-sulfur mixture again, take half-*liǎng* to cover the top, and place nine *qián* of gold-sulfur powder and two *qián* of raw sulfur into the container following the prior method. Seal the outer container as before, place it back in the ash pit, and follow the previous fire schedule by days.
Open the container, grind the mixture finely, and weigh it as before: one *liǎng* and six *qián*—the sulfur is now mostly subdued by fire.

Grind the gold-sulfur mixture again, add two *qián* of raw sulfur into the container, and cover the top with six *qián* of gold-sulfur powder. Seal it as before and nurture with fire according to the prior method until completion.
But add two *liǎng* of absolute sulfur—this is the limit.
If the container is small, switch to a larger one, following the method, totaling three *liǎng* and two *qián* of fire-subdued Supreme Ancestor’s elixir.

---
**Next: The Method of Nurturing Treasures**
Take small pieces of Cinnabar the size of beans.
First, use a clean, oil-free mortar, place the container’s powder inside, and add one *liǎng* of Cinnabar. Roast it slowly over low fire until it turns purple.

chunks.original_text: 放冷匮末，入在合内，以砂如我莲子成匀，固济，合三两火，养三日。 六两火，养七日。 开合，其砂如紫金色。 与前匮末同研，入汞二两，研无星，再入合，四两火，养七日。 开合取出，撇研此汞，为长生匮。 如糁制之功，用朱砂三两，如哉莲成匮内，上用匮末，更我朱砂一重，上更用匮末盖一重，依法固济，入灰池中，四两火，养七日。 开合子，朱砂三两，颗颗如金色，上槌可打如片。 但准此一法，养就二十两足。 将十两用七宝锅手，脱出真朱砂金八两，打作一金合子。 将砂十两研细，生硫一两同研匀，合了固了，入灰池中，依前养七日。 开合研细，此药可白，制汞成真金。 如旧将金合入匮末，不损匮末。 拨开中心作坑，倾汞四两在内，上以匮末盖，赤石脂固，入灰池，四两火，养一伏时，成金一锅。 此法须详，更有口诀，方可成药。 仍须有福德之人，修之必然成也。 无福德者，不可修炼。 次入金池法 衫子软金有方。

Grind it uniformly with the previous container’s powder, add two *liǎng* of mercury, and grind until no specks remain. Return it to the crucible, heat with four *liǎng* of fire, and nurture for seven days. Open the crucible, sift, and grind the mercury—this becomes the **Elixir of Longevity**.

Grind the remaining ten *liǎng* of cinnabar finely, mix uniformly with one *liǎng* of raw sulfur, seal it in the crucible, and place it in the ash pit. Nurture as before for seven days. chunks.original_text: 碧矾、黄矾各一钱，紫矾、绛矾各一两，四味并以火伏研末，醋一升，煮金鱼目沸，取金器烧赤，投入华池内，文火烧金似赤，於醋槽中，乘热便入华池中，能令赤色正定，黄紫光眩目。 每褊须皆以乌梅汤，以故毡毛揩拭。 次入润金华池法 清油一升，黄牛脂、堵脂各一斤，白硝石八两，小便四升。 右先煮油热，下牛脂消耗六分，下小便，更四十余沸，即下硝石、朴硝二味，候成汁，以金入池内，即润泽奇妙。 前匮内用药体法，在次篇中。 如后法，凡入匮之物，皆阴制阳，伏方成至宝。 所为诸丹，皆阴制结胎，而后阳伏成形。 其诸灭晕之药，若丹阳伏成形，则无色也。 见火多燥。 若只阴制成形，其色多暗。 大凡制伏金硫八石药，皆先须阴伏，后入阳炉，此法通妙也。 如用金曩朱砂，入匮便成金。 若银箔曩朱砂，入匮则成银。 焙不用母，自然成宝也。 如入少母，生焙亦妙矣。 伏火矾法 硫二两硝二两马兜铃三钱半。 右为末，拌匀，掘坑，入药於罐，内与地平。 将熟火一块弹子大，下放裹面，烟渐起，以湿纸四五重盖，用方砖两片，捺以土冢之。 候冷取出，其硫黄住。 每白矾三两，入伏火硫黄二两为末，大甘锅一个，以药在内，扇成汁，倾石器中，其色如玉也。 伏青盐法 青盐一斤，入甘锅内，用桑嫖峭二两许，调之自然成汁。 进七宝锅子法 白蔽、白友、糯米、枣肉、桑火灰、白垩子、赤石脂，右为细末，水和成锅子了，乾用。 口传秘诀 《修炼金丹变化金石下篇》曰：太上说此金石之法者，盖欲济世利人，使人知道可修，如术之有验矣。 非正令无情金石，变成至宝。 傥人修炼服之，则延寿长年，庾矣。 何其后人遇之者全少，不遇者殊多。 居当贵则贪好荣华嗜欲，处贫贱则矜於欺罔奸诈，如斯之人，虽遇此法，皆不能修养。 设使修制，亦不能成，盖无福德之助也。 故此太上圣祖匮法，实太上之所说者，秘之金匮玉函，世人无有知者。 余授此法於有道之士，令传受太上之法，利身利世，养生修炼。 至真之士遂拜受之后，初养不成，亦无物不损。 再於师前，乃受口诀，火候上数言而已。 余遂又依法及口诀，养之便成匮。 余今不避，轻泄天机。 依传口诀及经验，养药过度，并内外匮中合子用要，伏火之药饵，尽心口传秘诀，重编刊之于后。 庶使得遇之人，同志修炼，诀所就矣。 凡欲修炼，先须选择名山大川，或观宇，或净室，方可安药。 若所居处，在昔屠坊囚狱、坟墓产室，及有伏尸鬼魅，人足常到处，虚用心力，不可安炉。 次有魔也。 凡安炉，须先严净斋洁净室，三日或七日。 先祭醮所在神只，供养太上真容，若此则鬼魅亦来护助。 仍须逐日持念经呎，无缺香火，此乃养药之先要，不可不知法也。 夫法用黄者，盖方出山泽之麸金，其受天地之灵气尚在，固养之可以变化。 设或熟金之类，皆是触恶之物，不可入大药。 然而法中不用他药为匮，而独用金硫者，盖子母可以产化之灵也。 凡销金汁及用匮合之类，皆须以新未曾用者。 及将经用器物，并以乳香水浴过，安神圣前，洁净处安炉，下药时大忌鸡犬妇人见。 及深密，毋使闲人知之，亦须戒慎。 其法内说分两，须是仔细，切忌分两不匀。 若失之毫厘，药飞坏也。

「Use two *qián* each of **green vitriol** (*bì fēn*) and **yellow vitriol** (*huáng fēn*), one *liǎng* each of **purple vitriol** (*zǐ fēn*) and **crimson vitriol** (*jiàng fēn*). Grind all four into fine powder with **fire-refined** (*fú*) methods. Take one *shēng* of vinegar, boil it with **goldfish scales** (*jīn yú mù*) until it bubbles, then heat a gold vessel until it turns red, and immerse it into the **flowering crucible** (*huā huī*). Apply gentle heat until the gold vessel glows like molten gold. While still hot, quickly immerse it into the vinegar bath—this will fix its red hue and make the yellow and purple radiance dazzling.

For each batch, use **plum soup** (*wū méi tāng*) to cleanse, wiping with black felt.

**Next: The Method of Moistening the Golden Crucible**
One *shēng* of **clear oil** (*qīng yóu*), one *jīn* each of **yellow cow fat** (*huáng niú zhī*) and **pork fat** (*dǔ zhī*), eight *liǎng* of **white nitre** (*bái xiāo shí*), and four *shēng* of urine. First, heat the oil until boiling, then add the cow fat and reduce it by six *fēn*. Add the urine, boil for over forty times, then introduce the **white nitre** (*bái xiāo*) and **raw natron** (*pò xiāo*). When it forms a liquid, immerse the gold vessel—it will be moistened with marvelous luster.

The **powdered crucible** (*huī mò*) method is detailed in the following section.

In general, all substances placed in the crucible undergo **yin suppression of yang** (*yīn zhì yáng*), and through **fire-refining** (*fú fāng*) they become supreme treasures. All **elixirs** (*dān*) are formed by first **yin-suppressing** (*yīn zhì*) to solidify the embryo, then **yang-refining** (*yáng fú*) to take shape.

If an elixir is **yang-refined** (*yáng fú*) to form its shape, it will be colorless. If only **yin-suppressed** (*yīn zhì*) to solidify, its hue will be dark. In essence, refining **gold and sulfur** (*jīn liú*) along with the **eight stones** (*bā shí*), one must first **yin-suppress** (*yīn fú*), then place in the **yang furnace** (*yáng lú*). This is a universal and wondrous method.

If **gold leaf** (*jīn piàn*) is mixed with **cinnabar** (*zhū shā*), it will turn into gold upon entering the crucible. If **silver foil** (*yín biè*) is mixed with cinnabar, it will become silver. Without the **mother substance** (*mǔ*), the **calcined product** (*bèi*) will naturally form a treasure. Even if a little mother is added, the calcined product will still be miraculous.

**The Method of Fire-Suppressed Vitriol**
Two *liǎng* of **sulfur** (*liú huáng*), two *liǎng* of **nitre** (*xiāo shí*), and three *qián* of **Aristolochia debilis** (*mǎ dòu líng*). Grind these into a powder, mix evenly, dig a pit, place the mixture in a jar, and level it with the ground.

Take a **fire-refined** (*fú*) fire block the size of a **prickly ash fruit** (*shān zhū*), wrap it with dough, and wait until smoke rises. Cover with four or five layers of damp paper, then seal with two square bricks, pressing down with an earthen mound. When cooled, remove it—the **sulfur** will remain intact.

For each three *liǎng* of **white vitriol** (*bái fēn*), mix with two *liǎng* of **fire-suppressed sulfur** (*fú huǒ liú huáng*) into a powder. Use a large **sweet crucible** (*dà gān huī*), place the mixture inside, and stir into a liquid. Pour it into a stone vessel—its color will be like jade.

**The Method of Fire-Suppressed Green Salt**
One *jīn* of **green salt** (*qīng yán*), placed in a sweet crucible with two *liǎng* of **mulberry twig ash** (*sāng yáo qiào*), will naturally form a liquid when mixed.

**The Method of the Nine-Precious Crucible**
**White lead** (*bái yǐ*), **white arsenic** (*bái yǒu*), glutinous rice, date flesh, **mulberry ash** (*sāng huǒ huī*), **white chalk** (*bái è zi*), and **red stone pitch** (*chì shí zhī*). Grind all into fine powder, mix with water to form a crucible paste, and dry it for use.

**Oral Transmission of the Secret Precept**
*The Lower Section of Daoist Alchemy: Transmuting Gold and Stone* says:
The **Supreme Sovereign** (*Tài Shàng*) teaches this gold-and-stone method to benefit the world and guide people, so they may know what can be cultivated—just as **alchemical techniques** (*shù*) have proven efficacy. It is not to command lifeless gold and stone to transform into supreme treasures.

If one cultivates and ingests this, it will prolong life and extend years—ah, the wonder! Yet few among later generations encounter it, while many do not. Those in high station covet fame and wealth, indulging in desires; those in lowly ranks are proud of deceit and trickery. Such people, though they meet this method, cannot cultivate it. Even if they attempt refinement, they cannot succeed—it is because they lack the **virtue and merit** (*fúdé*) to aid them.

Thus, the **Supreme Sovereign’s** sacred crucible method is truly what the **Supreme Sovereign** spoke of, sealed in the **Golden Crucible and Jade Casket** (*jīn huī yù hán*), unknown to the world. I impart this method to **Daoist adepts** (*yǒu dào zhī shì*), so they may transmit and uphold the **Supreme Sovereign’s** teachings, benefiting themselves and the world, nurturing life and refining treasures.

The **truly authentic** (*zhì zhēn*) adept bowed in reception, but even after the first cultivation, nothing succeeded, and all materials were wasted. Only then, before his teacher, did he receive the **oral precepts** (*kǒu jué*), a few words on fire and timing.

I then followed the method and precepts, and the crucible was cultivated successfully. Now, I reveal no more, lightly divulging the **Dao’s** mysteries. According to transmitted precepts and experience, if the cultivation exceeds the proper degree, the **inner and outer crucible** (*nèi wài huī*) paste and the **fire-suppressed** (*fú huǒ*) medicines must be carefully measured—do not let the proportions be uneven. If even a **hair’s breadth** (*háo lí*) is lost, the medicine will fail.

To refine, one must first select **numinous mountains and great rivers** (*míng shān dà chuān*), or a **pure hall** (*guān yǔ*), or a **cleansed chamber** (*jìng shì*). Only then can the medicine be safely placed. If the dwelling is in former **slaughterhouses** (*tú fáng*), **prisons** (*qiú yù*), **graves** (*fén mù*), **birth chambers** (*chǎn shì*), or places with lingering **corpses** (*fú shī*), **ghosts** (*guǐ mèi*), or frequented by **worldly feet** (*rén zú cháng dào*), the effort will be in vain—**the crucible cannot be set**.

**Next: The Method of Warding Off Demons**
Before setting the crucible, one must first observe **strict fasting** (*yán zhāi*), purify the chamber, and maintain **ritual cleanliness** (*jié jìng*) for three or seven days. Sacrifice and offer to the **local deities** (*shè jiào shén zhī*), and present the **Supreme Sovereign’s** true image. Then even **ghosts and demons** will come to guard and assist.

Daily, one must recite and meditate on **sutras** (*jīng*), never neglecting incense—this is the **primary essential** (*xiān yào*) for nurturing the medicine. One must not fail to know the method.

The method uses **yellow** (*huáng*), for it is the **dross of gold and stone** (*mǐ jīn*) freshly extracted from mountains and rivers, still retaining the **numinous qi** (*líng qì*) of heaven and earth—thus it can be refined and transformed. If one uses **matured gold** (*shú jīn*), it is a **tainted substance** (*chù è zhī wù*), unfit for the **great medicine** (*dà yào*).

Yet the method does not rely on other medicines for the crucible paste, using only **gold and sulfur**—for the **mother and child** (*zǐ mǔ*) can generate the **embryonic qi** (*huà zhī líng*). All **gold-liquid** (*xiāo jīn zhī*) and crucible-paste mixtures must use **new, unused materials** (*xīn wèi céng yòng zhě*).

When using vessels for the process, they must all be bathed in **frankincense water** (*rǔ xiāng shuǐ*), placed before the **sacred altar** (*shén shèng*), and set in a **pure chamber** (*jié jìng chǔ*). At the moment of placing the medicine, **chickens, dogs, women, and children** (*jī quǎn fù rén*) must not be present—this is a **great taboo** (*dà jì*).

The method must be kept in **deep secrecy** (*shēn mì*), and no **idle person** (*xián rén*) should know of it. One must also exercise **caution and reverence** (*jiè shèn*).

The method’s proportions must be **meticulously precise** (*fèn liàng zǐ xì*). If even a **hair’s breadth** (*háo lí*) is miscalculated, the medicine will **disperse and ruin** (*yào fēi huài*).」

chunks.original_text: 夫金硫惟抚细如缅为上，若粗，进火两日不一日难透。 凡固济，须是依法仔细。 先阴得匮乾，然后日乾。 若有风裂缺损，并不可用。 须择吉日，方可入炉。 凡云三两火，养三日者，即是每一伏时，以火三两。 余准此。 但每将匮合，先入灰池内，其灰池须柴火灰、纸灰相拌，四面以匙将灰捺实。 即以火筋校合子一寸来阔，灰令彻底虚后，将称到熟火，褊簇合上，以灰盖覆，毋令透风，及不缺火。 其火自得，多时不化。 近合子灰，切不可紧，紧则火力不行，火外面。 灰四向却须是紧实。 若犯之一切触污，及用火失度，亦走失损也。 如增匮头，走却硫黄，但据所走者锱铢，依法别进，再依前来日数养，候日数足，开称如不折，便次更增硫黄，候数足臧增之。 凡进朱砂，须先入净室，器量多少入水，用土、马鬃、硼砂、炮砂各少许，文武火煮一伏时取出，后再依法制入匮。 凡糁制之法难为，此法甚奇捷，但毋终久，无尽其匮，至此以为验。 但更依法入汞，每一伏时，取物四两也，决有准矣。 其物初出，莫便见猛风。 仍先乌梅、包金，土虎、耳草各半许，同物於石器，水煮一伏时，复入锅子，灶三次，方可用。 今恐遗此并匮头口诀，尽录藏之，永为家宝，非人勿示焉。 大唐元和三年戊申甲子月壬申日，金华洞清虚子撰。 九转出尘糁制大丹 第一转 诗曰：

The **gold and sulfur** must be ground as fine as **Myanmar lac**—if coarse, even two days of fire may not suffice to penetrate it.

For **solidifying the elixir**, one must proceed with meticulous care according to the method. First, dry the **vessel in the shade**, then dry it in the sun. If cracks or damage appear from wind, it must not be used. Only on an **auspicious day** may it be placed in the furnace.

When the text speaks of **"three measures of fire, nurtured for three days,"** it means three measures of fire for each **one *fúshí*** period. The rest follows this proportion.

Before combining the **vessel**, first place it in an **ash pit**, mixing the ash with **firewood ash and paper ash**, then tamp the ash firmly on all sides with a spoon. Use a **fire-tempered spatula** to seal the vessel’s opening—one *cùn* wide—ensuring the ash beneath is hollowed through. Then, when the fire is fully kindled, quickly cover the vessel’s mouth, seal it with ash, and ensure no wind leaks in or the fire extinguishes. If the fire lingers too long without transformation, examine the ash near the vessel—it must not be tightly packed, for if it is, the fire’s power will stagnate and retreat outward. The ash on all sides, however, must be firmly compacted.

If any impurity is introduced or the fire is mismanaged, the **sulfur will dissipate and be lost**. If the **vessel’s head is increased**, the sulfur will flee—measure the lost amount precisely, then supplement it according to the method, nurturing it again for the required days. Once the days are complete and the vessel is opened without fracture, proceed to add more sulfur, continuing until the desired quantity is achieved.

When introducing **cinnabar**, first place it in a **pure chamber**, measuring the amount to be immersed in water, then boil with **earth, horsehair, borax, and roasted sand** in gentle and fierce fires for one *fúshí* period before proceeding with the elixir’s preparation.

The method of **grinding the elixir** is difficult, yet this technique is swift and extraordinary—only cease when the **vessel is fully exhausted**, confirming its efficacy.

Then, according to the method, introduce **mercury**, taking four *liǎng* of the substance per *fúshí* period—this is the definitive measure.

When the substance first emerges, do not expose it to **violent winds**. Instead, first boil **black plum, wrapped gold, earth tiger, and eargrass** (each half a portion) with the substance in a stone vessel for one *fúshí* period, then transfer it to a **triple-fired pot** before use.

Now, lest these **secrets of the vessel and elixir head** be lost, I record them all for preservation as a **family treasure**, to be shown to none. Composed on the **3rd year of Yuanhe in the Great Tang, on the *jiǎzǐ* day of the *wùshēn* month**, by **Qīngxū Zǐ of Jīnhuā Cave**.

chunks.original_text: 三黄二子及猜牙，苍木还同蔺麦花。 大火炼成通体黑，丹砂从此是根芽。 右法缎朱草，以大黄、黄苓、黄药子、次明子、褚牙皂角、苍木、冬麦花，七味为末，入建盏，铺盖辰砂五两，捺实，小盏覆盖，铁线十字结，固济，令乾。 灰抱定合实，二斤火一焕。 冷开取出草灰，其辰砂黑色。 如此四次，共暖二十两。 方入后段，每铅二两，对砒一两。 以铅先入甘锅内，镕成汁子，却将枇块投入铅汁中，候火烟尽提退冷，打破枇铅分胎，枇在上，铅在下，用砒不用铅。 砒如琥珀色，通红。 暖得枇二十两，与丹砂二十两，同研匀，入甘锅，瓦陀盖口，入炉暖红提出，放坐温灰中冷，打破其丹成宝，如一块生银可爱。 其枇无颜色，不用。 此丹砂成宝，号日青金头。 要用硬石好炭排布炉内，煽红火猛，却入甘锅了，以元瓦盖上，再用熟火盖之，用煽候作声，朱成宝，却提起。 第二转煮出铅黑 诗日： 磕破青金更莫疑，玄胎煮炼两三时。 药神逼去黄芽气，功效如神神可奇。 右以草乌、川椒、白矾、龙骨、五倍子、甘草、磁石、狼毒、南星针、砂十味药，入米醋中，将青金头打作片子，入生绢袋中，悬胎煮三日夜，又以沸煮一日，三次淘洗，要去铅气，方培为匮。 第三转青金匮朱砂成宝 诗曰： 伏火朱砂甚足夸，将来为匮养神砂。 褊铺合内哉莲样，五日功成更可嘉。 右将煮了青金砂为末，作匮，顶火四两，子午卯酉换虚，养五日足，铅气已断，却通灵也。 暖信硼作母砂贴身法： 右将白芍药、知母、石斛，烧烟需甘锅令黑，烧红，以硼信等分，入甘锅成汁，倾出如玉色也。 明净朱砂，以米醋润过，以三七母砂逐块袅，更裒蜜，以椒末贴身，入前宝匮内，如前火候，固养七日足。 取出砂铁色，可垒至一斤作长生丹阳匮，养灵砂。 若不作匮，铅煎成宝得八分。 第四转丹阳匮灵砂见宝 诗日： 养出丹砂能换骨，切言造化脱灵砂。 入炉七日成仙体，若遇铅池号雪花。 右丹阳三斤，灵砂四两，重以醋润银末，贴身入匮，子午卯酉火四两，养七日，一斤火就缎。 冷开垒作匮，或见宝体，皆可爱。 第五转超凡入圣养母砂成宝 诗曰： 火力相资入大钧，丹阳为匮愈通神。 超凡入圣趁真境，五日陶成出世珍。 暖硼信法见三转内，又取丹阳匮中，养黄灶成银，结成三七母砂。 五钱一九，白矾盐汤煮一伏时，硬了，蜜润贴身，入前丹阳匮内，子午卯酉四两火，养五日足，二斤火缎。 此匮经火五次养母砂后，方入第六转。 第六转养七宝成大药匮 诗曰： 朱砂体性合雌雄，更和硫黄至圣功。 三七母砂包曩定，丸成灵宝入其中。 右以前五次积火养成丹阳匮末二两，入生朱砂，与三黄各一两。 汞一两，研细不见星。 以芸香草二两，入姚化汁。 次下众药末炒之，慢火即成膏，刀刮九如弹子大，乾如铁。 次用圣银结三七母砂，贴身，入前五积火大匮内，如前火养七日，二斤火暖。 次开如金弹子，号日大药也。 积得三十两，作匮养后段。 第七转朱砂糁制 诗曰： 七宝源流养大还，朱砂受气共成丹。 一朝造化参真宰，乾汞成金顷刻问。 右将三十两七宝药为匮，生硫三两，生朱砂七两，用楮汁九如弹子大，入宝匮，如前火候固济，养七日，不缎。 冷开，朱硫弹子紫金色，精神沉重，光泽夺目。

**First Transformation of the Nine-Turns Beyond-Dust Elixir (Continued)**

**Refinement of the Nine-Turn Elixir**
*Method:*
Take **three yellows** (rhubarb, scutellaria, and evodia), **two children** (bitter apricot kernel, soapberry), **guess-tooth** (soapberry), **blue wood**, and **winter wheat flower**, each ground into powder. Place in a **building cup**, layering with **cinnabar** (five *liǎng*), pressing firmly. Cover with a small cup, bind with iron wire in a cross, secure tightly, and dry.

Wrap in ash, bake with two *jīn* of fire until fully heated. Once cooled, remove the grass ash—now the cinnabar is black. Repeat this process four times, yielding twenty *liǎng* of warmed cinnabar.

Proceed to the next stage: for every two *liǎng* of lead, use one *liǎng* of arsenic. First, melt the lead in a **sweet crucible** into a liquid, then add **pistachio blocks** into the molten lead. When the smoke clears and the fire cools, break the pistachio-lead mass—lead forms the lower layer, pistachio the upper. Discard the lead; the arsenic, now **amber-red and translucent**, is retained.

Warm twenty *liǎng* of pistachio with twenty *liǎng* of cinnabar, grinding them evenly. Place in a sweet crucible, cover with a **glazed tile**, and heat in the furnace until red. Remove and cool in warm ash, then break open to reveal the cinnabar as a **precious mass**, like fresh silver—this is the **Green-Gold Head**.

The pistachio, now colorless, is discarded. This refined cinnabar is now called the **Green-Gold Head**.

*Poem:*
**Second Transformation: Cooking Lead into Black**
*"Smash the Green-Gold Head without doubt,
The primordial embryo simmers for two or three hours.
The medicinal spirit expels the yellow sprout’s breath,
Its efficacy divine—truly wondrous."*

*Method:*
Take **aconite, Sichuan pepper, alum, dragon bone, gallnut, licorice, magnetite, wolfsbane, arisaema needle, and sand** (ten herbs), steep in rice vinegar. Shape the Green-Gold Head into flakes, encase in raw silk, and suspend for **three days and nights of boiling**, then **one day of vigorous boiling**, washing three times to purge the lead essence. Then, form it into a **vessel**.

**Third Transformation: Green-Gold Vessel, Cinnabar Becomes Precious**
*Poem:*
*"The cinnabar, nurtured by hidden fire, is most praiseworthy,
Now formed as a vessel to foster the divine sand.
Layered within like a lotus, five days’ work—truly commendable."*

*Method:*
Grind the cooked Green-Gold cinnabar into powder, forming a vessel. Use **four *liǎng* of fire** at the **child and adult hours**, nurturing for five days until the lead essence is severed and the spirit awakens.

**Method for Warming Borax into Mother Sand (Attaching to the Body):**
Take **white peony, anemarrhena, and dendrobium**, burning them in a sweet crucible until blackened, then reddening. Add equal parts **borax**, melting into a liquid like jade. Moisten pure cinnabar with rice vinegar, then layer with **three-sevens mother sand** (in seven-to-three ratios), wrap in honey, and dust with pepper. Place inside the previous vessel, using the same fire regimen, nurturing for seven days. The extracted sand is now **iron-colored**, sufficient to form a *jīn* for the **Dan-Yang Vessel**, fostering the **spiritual sand**.

If not formed into a vessel, the lead can be refined into a precious mass of **eight *liǎng***.

**Fourth Transformation: Dan-Yang Vessel, Spiritual Sand Reveals the Precious**
*Poem:*
*"Nurtured cinnabar can transmute the bones,
Speak truly—creation refines the spiritual sand.
Seven days in the furnace yields an immortal form,
If it meets the lead pool, it’s called Snow Flower."*

*Method:*
Take **three *jīn* of Dan-Yang** and **four *liǎng* of spiritual sand**, moistening with vinegar and silver powder. Attach to the body and place in the vessel, using **four *liǎng* of fire** at the child, adult, and hour of the dragon and rooster. Nurture for seven days—one *jīn* of fire suffices per refinement. Cool, then reassemble into a vessel. If the precious form appears, it is cherished.

**Fifth Transformation: Transcending the Mundane, Entering Sagehood—Nurturing Mother Sand into Precious**
*Poem:*
*"Fire’s power aids the Great Axis,
The Dan-Yang Vessel grows ever more divine.
Transcending the mundane, entering sagehood in true essence,
Five days of baking yields a worldly treasure."*

*Method:*
From the **third transformation**, take the Dan-Yang vessel’s cinnabar, refining it into silver in a **yellow furnace**, forming **three-sevens mother sand** (five *qián* to nine *qián*). Boil in **alum-salt broth** for one *fúshí* period, then harden, moisten with honey, and attach to the body. Place inside the previous Dan-Yang vessel, using **four *liǎng* of fire** at the child, adult, and hour of the dragon and rooster. Nurture for five days—two *jīn* of fire suffices. After five refinements of fire nurturing the mother sand, proceed to the **sixth transformation**.

**Sixth Transformation: Nurturing the Seven Treasures into the Great Medicine Vessel**
*Poem:*
*"The cinnabar’s nature unites yin and yang,
Sulfur’s sacred function now merges.
The three-sevens mother sand encloses the former,
Pill formed—divine treasure within."*

*Method:*
Take the accumulated fire from the first five transformations, grinding the Dan-Yang vessel into powder (**two *liǎng***), adding **raw cinnabar** and **three yellows** (each one *liǎng*), and **mercury** (one *liǎng*), finely ground until no stars remain. Mix with **two *liǎng* of patchouli grass** in **yao-hua juice**, then layer the other herbs, slow-firing into a paste. Shape into nine **marble-sized pills**, drying them like iron. Use **holy silver** to form the three-sevens mother sand, attach to the body, and place in the previous five-times-fired vessel. Nurture for seven days with **two *jīn* of fire**. When opened, it resembles a **golden marble**—this is the **Great Medicine**.

Accumulate thirty *liǎng* to form a vessel for the later stages.

**Seventh Transformation: Cinnabar Beyond-Dust Refinement**
*Poem:*
*"The Seven Treasures’ source returns to the Great,
Cinnabar receives *qi* to forge the elixir.
One day, creation aligns with the True Sovereign,
Mercury and cinnabar become gold in an instant."*

*Method:*
Take the **thirty *liǎng* of Seven Treasures** to form a vessel. Add **three *liǎng* of raw sulfur** and **seven *liǎng* of raw cinnabar**, shaping with **mulberry juice** into nine marble-sized pills. Place in the treasure vessel, using the same fire regimen, nurturing for seven days without refinement. When cooled, the cinnabar-sulfur pills are **purple-gold**, dense with spirit, their luster dazzling.

**Eighth Transformation: Beyond-Dust Refinement**
*Poem:*
*"The Dao’s elixir transcends life and death,
Transforming mortal flesh for those with resolve.
Not only does mercury revive the dead—
Who knows that mortal bones may ascend to the heavens?"*

*Method:*
Reduce to powder. For every three *qián*, refine one *liǎng* of mercury into treasure. Take fresh iron filings, moistened with hundred-flower honey, and add ten *liǎng* of mercury. Mix in one *liǎng* of cinnabar powder, seal with a lid, and secure the seams with vinegar and red stone pitch. Apply a moderate fire of four *liǎng*, listening for internal rumbling—this is the *dry* phase. The cinnabar-mercury mixture remains unchanged; sweep it into the vessel to nurture. Refine again until the mercury is free of dust, then nurture for one year, yielding one grain per *liǎng*.

**Ninth Transformation: The Purple Cloud Great Elixir**
*Poem:*
*"Believe that all possess hidden realms—
Sincere cultivation reveals the truth.
The Purple Cloud Elixir nears Penglai’s shores,
When refined, its hue is green as fate’s decree."*

*Method:*
Take the accumulated thirty *liǎng* of Seven Treasures, ground into powder, to form the vessel. Add seven *liǎng* of transparent cinnabar, also powdered, shaping with mulberry juice into nine pills—do not handle with bare hands. Place in the vessel, seal tightly, and apply four *liǎng* of fire. Nurture for forty-nine days during the *zi-wu-xiao-you* hours. Cool in a cold furnace, burn incense, and pay homage to the Three Pure Ones. When opened, its radiance dazzles. Reduce to powder, shape with nine dates into the size of *wu tong* seeds, encase in crimson silk, and submerge in a well one *chi* below water. After seven days, the toxic fire is purged—this is the **Purple Cloud Great Elixir**. One grain refines one *liǎng* of mercury into ten *fen* of *gēng*.

Ingesting it, one sheds the mortal coil and ascends as an immortal, transcending to sainthood.

chunks.original_text: 子午灵砂法 灵砂，其桑灰要三四淋，浓汁煮方下，不侵母。 此灵砂打时，不要十分碎。 第一煅 灵砂不以多少，研作小骰子块，以桑灰汁，煮二伏时，取出。 每一两煮了，取灵砂，用六钱银末，一两二钱汞，同入铁跳，结成一两半母砂。 厚曩法，用盥一斤，知母四两，研细和炒令烟，待知母烟尽，去知母，以盐安合子内，将暑了灵砂，如我莲状，哉褊合子内，上用砂盥盖之，合定，以赤石脂固济，可厚半寸，日乾，埋於灰缸内。 第日二日夜，顶火四两。 三日四日夜，合顶火五两。 五日六日夜，顶火六两。 七日，顶火七两，至夜顶火半斤。 第· 八日早，去余火。 伺合子十分冷，去泥开取灵砂，不得去曩者母砂。 次用菠棱子、苦贾子、搭水花、田字草、金灯草根，五味为末，以紫葛自然汁搜逐一球，定其灵砂，入鼎内。 如三才法，七八斤火缎之，火消自至成汁，出灵炒去母砂。 次方入铅池煎，．以一两灵砂，用铅一两煎之。 第二煅 以煎煮银错为末，结母砂，煮养火缎之。 第三煅 汞八两，石停脂二两，雄黄一两，用制研为末，匀倾入跳内，炒青金头，打灵砂，煮毁如前法。 若不变转，只依匮子煮养时，只依第三缎，缎了灵砂为末，每四两末，可汞一两。 和研不见星为度。 且率以二十两为匮合，抚五两汞，即以十两灵砂末，五两汞同研不见星。 外有十两，分五两入甍合底，次同汞抚者十五两，安在中心，又以无汞者五两末盖面，以合合之，赤石脂泥固济缝，通身以纸筋泥固济，入灰池内，七日至半斤火足。 寒炉，轻轻以铁匙，挑取面上五两无汞末，次取中十五两有汞者，又取合底五两无汞者。 将此上下无汞者十两，作一处。 又用汞七两同研，不见粉星。 即以前来先捻养有汞者，分为两处，将一半先入合底，即将近和汞末在中问，又以前来一半末盖面，固济如前法，入灰缸，增火养。 并亦如前法。 七日取出，一处抚匀，仍汞八两同研，固济养火复如前，二十两灵砂，共成四十两匮。 此谓之喂谈登对法。 此可养母砂及粉霜，冬之后见火多，而愈有力，而无黄土头之义。 若觉十数养取物，其匮有枯色。 四十两匮，可研一十两汞入内，合白养其匮，取出养物又滋润。 才觉枯色，又四两研一两汞，喂之精增不竭，斤愈灵。 第四煅 以汞八两，雌雄各一两。 先将硫汞交媾了，方得将雌雄同打作灵砂，煮养火了，不用母砂，但於第三匮内，养七日，其火候亦如第三煅喂谈登对了，方可作匮，而养庚砂，七七日而成匮。 养若觉枯，喂谈如前法。 第五煅 用三黄灵砂煮了，入第四匮，养出灵砂，喂谈登对，更入盥匮。 及不用母砂，包草药此匮，宜养金砂更灵。 以七钱点一两赤肉，渐有脚靴皮之虫。 第六 用三黄灵砂，不用煮，只於第五灵砂匮内，养火七日，取出看意下，要取多少两数。 此第六毁灵砂，可以七钱点一两赤肉，成真丹阳换骨，乃正脚黑□二法也。 此方可入死龙蟠，亦曰白雪，又日明窗尘也。 第七死龙蟠法 用鼎法 几以第六转灵砂一两，对汞一两，细研不见星为度，法正三十三两。 三十两灵砂，同三十两汞，合研成六十两，入鼎，朝升暮降，打作白雪。 上下鼎身周十二寸，以应十二月。 身长八寸，以应八节。

**The *Zi-Wu Ling-Sha* Method of Nourishing Mercury**

**Ling-Sha**, when its mulberry ash is refined, must be washed three or four times with concentrated juice before cooking—do not let it contaminate the original. When pounding it, avoid excessive fragmentation.

**First Refining**
Ling-Sha, regardless of quantity, is ground into small dice-like blocks. With mulberry ash juice, it is cooked for two *fú* periods, then removed. For every *liǎng* cooked, take the Ling-Sha and mix with six *qiǎn* of silver powder and one *liǎng* two *qiǎn* of mercury, combining them in an iron mortar to form one *liǎng* half of **nourished Ling-Sha**.

**Thickened Layering Method**
Use one *jīn* of **alumen** (*fǎng*), four *liǎng* of **anemarrhena** (*zhī mǔ*), finely ground and stir-fried until smoke rises. Once the smoke from anemarrhena dissipates, remove it and place the Ling-Sha in a sealed vessel with salt. When the Ling-Sha has thickened like a lotus, add it to the vessel, cover with **alumen** (*shā fǎng*), seal tightly, and secure with **red stone pitch** (*chì shí zhī*), making it half an inch thick. Let it dry daily, then bury it in an ash jar.

On the **second and third nights**, apply four *liǎng* of fire.
On the **fourth and fifth nights**, apply five *liǎng* of fire.
On the **sixth and seventh nights**, apply six *liǎng* of fire.
By the **seventh night**, apply half a *jīn* of fire.

**Eighth Day**
Remove the excess fire.
Wait until the vessel is thoroughly cold, then scrape off the dirt and open it to retrieve the Ling-Sha—**do not discard the thickened layers (the nourished Ling-Sha)**.

Next, use **balanofruit** (*bō lèng zǐ*), **bitter cardamom** (*kǔ jiǎ zǐ*), **water caltrop** (*dā shuǐ huā*), **Chinese yarrow** (*tián zì cǎo*), and **golden lampwort root** (*jīn dēng cǎo gēn*), finely ground into five powders. With **purple hemp juice** (*zǐ gé zìrán zhī*), knead them into one ball, securing the Ling-Sha inside. Place in a crucible and refine with **seven to eight *jīn* of fire**, until the flames subside and the liquid forms. Remove the **nourished Ling-Sha** (*líng shāo*), discarding the original.

Next, refine in the **lead cauldron** (*qiān chí jiān*), using one *liǎng* of Ling-Sha to one *liǎng* of lead.

**Second Refining**
With the refined silver powder, knead the original Ling-Sha and cook it with fire as before.

**Third Refining**
Use eight *liǎng* of mercury, two *liǎng* of **realgar** (*shí tíng zhī*), and one *liǎng* of **orpiment** (*xióng huáng*), ground and mixed into a powder. Evenly pour into the mortar, stir-fry to a **green-gold head**, pound the Ling-Sha, and cook it as before. If it does not transform, only follow the **vessel-nourishing method** during the third refining: refine the Ling-Sha into powder, and for every four *liǎng* of powder, use one *liǎng* of mercury. Knead until no grains remain.

Generally, for a **twenty-*liǎng* vessel**, use five *liǎng* of mercury. Take ten *liǎng* of Ling-Sha powder and five *liǎng* of mercury, kneading them until no grains remain. Of the remaining ten *liǎng*, place five *liǎng* at the vessel’s base, then layer the kneaded mercury mixture (fifteen *liǎng*) in the center, and finally cover with the remaining five *liǎng* of mercury-free powder. Seal the vessel with **red stone pitch** (*chì shí zhī*) and mud, wrapping its entire body with **paper-fiber mud** (*zhǐ gēn ní*), then bury it in an ash pit for seven days until half a *jīn* of fire is sufficient.

In a **cold furnace**, gently use an iron spoon to scoop out the top five *liǎng* of mercury-free powder, then the central fifteen *liǎng* of mercury-infused powder, and finally the bottom five *liǎng* of mercury-free powder. Combine the top and bottom mercury-free portions (ten *liǎng*) into one.

Use seven *liǎng* of mercury to knead the remaining portion until no powder grains remain. Take half of the earlier kneaded mixture and place it at the vessel’s base, layer the newly kneaded mercury mixture (fifteen *liǎng*) in the center, and cover with the remaining half of the earlier mixture. Seal as before, bury in the ash jar, and increase the fire for nourishing. Follow the same method as earlier.

After seven days, remove it. Combine the upper and lower layers, then knead with eight *liǎng* of mercury. Seal and refine with fire as before, resulting in **forty *liǎng* of vessel-nourished Ling-Sha**. This is called the **Feeding and Refinement Method**.

This can nourish **Ling-Sha** and **mercury powder** (*fěn shuāng*). After winter, increased fire enhances its **virtue/power** (*dé*), without the **yellow soil head** (*huáng tǔ tóu*) flaw. If the vessel appears dry after several refinements, add four *liǎng* of powder to one *liǎng* of mercury, feeding it to restore **virtue/power** (*dé*) without depletion—each *liǎng* becomes more refined.

**Fourth Refining**
Use eight *liǎng* of mercury and one *liǎng* each of **male and female sulfur** (*zhuāng xióng*).

First, **intercourse** (*jiāo gōu*) the sulfur and mercury, then refine the male and female sulfur together into Ling-Sha. Cook and refine with fire as before—**do not use the original Ling-Sha**. Instead, within the third vessel, nourish for seven days, adjusting the fire as in the **Feeding and Refinement Method**. Only then form the vessel, and refine **Gēng-Sha** (*gēng*) over **seven sevens** (*qī qī*) days.

If it appears dry during nourishment, follow the **Feeding and Refinement Method** as before.

**Fifth Refining**
Use **three-yellow Ling-Sha** refined earlier, place it in the fourth vessel, and refine the Ling-Sha again with the **Feeding and Refinement Method**, then return it to the **alumen** vessel. **Do not use the original Ling-Sha**; instead, wrap it with herbal medicine in this vessel to refine **golden Ling-Sha** (*jīn shā*) more effectively. Use seven *qiǎn* to refine one *liǎng* of **red flesh** (*chì ròu*), gradually producing **soles-of-shoes skin** (*jiǎo xuē pí*)—the **true elixir** (*zhēn dān*) for **yang transformation** (*yáng huàn*) and **bone-changing** (*gǔ*).

**Sixth Refining**
Use **three-yellow Ling-Sha** without cooking—only within the fifth vessel’s refined Ling-Sha, nourish with fire for seven days. Remove and examine the quantity; take as much as desired. This **sixth refining** of Ling-Sha can use seven *qiǎn* to refine one *liǎng* of **red flesh** (*chì ròu*), achieving the **true elixir** (*zhēn dān*) for **yang transformation** (*yáng huàn*) and **bone-changing** (*gǔ*)—the **orthodox method for blackening the soles** (*zhèng jiǎo hēi* □).

This can be used in the **Dead Dragon Coiling** (*sǐ lóng pán*) method, also called **White Snow** (*bái xuě*) or **Bright Window Dust** (*míng chuāng chén*).

**Seventh Refining: Dead Dragon Coiling Method**
Using the **crucible method** (*dǐng fǎ*), for every one *liǎng* of the sixth-refined Ling-Sha, knead with one *liǎng* of mercury until no grains remain—**the standard ratio is thirty-three *liǎng*** (*fǎ zhèng sānshān sān liǎng*). Combine thirty *liǎng* of Ling-Sha with thirty *liǎng* of mercury, kneading into sixty *liǎng*, then place in the crucible. **Rise in the morning, descend in the evening**, pounding it into **White Snow** (*bái xuě*).

The crucible’s height is twelve *cùn* around its circumference, corresponding to the **twelve months**. Its length is eight *cùn*, corresponding to the **eight seasonal nodes** (*bā jié*).

chunks.original_text: 上鼎身阔，倍下鼎一倍，乃按二十四气。 上鼎为天，下鼎为地，上升为阳，下降为阴，阴气欲升，阳气欲降，此应阴阳之陶冶也。 尺寸阔狭，不可大，不可小。 大则气散不聚，小则逼溢，故不能遂升降之匀和。 盖在於鼎，乃鼎中之包密，内调升降，外禀阴阳，以成天地造化之机矣。 上鼎围阔二十四寸，下作三级，与鼎唇口三级相合。 下鼎长八寸，身围十二寸，唇三级，与上鼎覆下三级相合，不得差殊。 此鼎不用足。 别打铁围令厚，以三钉钉作三足钉，可以大姆指厚，高二寸半。 次作阴阳二炉。 阴炉凿地作坑，埋一瓶，瓶口如大鼎，复大埋在地，与瓶口平。 次作余土．筑四边，如无地相似。 一阳炉，只平地迭成。 及以六十两药，入在鼎内，用赤石脂调稀泥，涂上下鼎三级方捺合，以铁线贯耳，固济。 如打灵砂法，用四时火，七昼夜，成其大功。 水火药三者，应天地人三才也。 四时火者，春火欲暖，夏火欲烈，秋火欲温，冬火欲微。 此法择子日子时，安鼎，安三足之上。 乃入阳炉， 鼎复底迭，至鼎身三分，用缓文火，用火使其内相交媾，一时半。 乃便暴火，簇炭至半鼎，一时辰半。 乃使烈火炭令盛上，增鼎身五分之三，一时辰半。 乃渐渐退火，用微火，令鼎内温温气定，一时辰半。 至午时，攘鼎起入阴炉，乃坐鼎腹，於小罐口上，用灰埋鼎身五分之三，乃以布渗去上鼎水乾，方可上鼎盘内，安火一斤，内春火也。 令鼎内之汞，徐徐而降投下，一时辰半方可。 自灰之上，迭炭簇火，渐暴一时半。 乃有盛簇火，自上鼎盘至灰上，皆生盛火烈，一时辰半方渐。 次去上鼎火，次徐徐而去下火，用微火令鼎内药定，温温一时辰半。 至半夜子时，复拨鼎入阳炉，依前一升一降，既济未济，七昼夜火功成矣。 破鼎，取出白雪少许，入气炉坏成汁，不折不耗，能事毕矣。 如或少许损折不色，别又使一鼎，如前法打升降七昼夜后，取出白雪汞，为大宝。 丹诗漏泄，取此死龙蟠如静，铁臼内研之如粉，使一薄铁合子，常常安白雪三分，之三以插长孔，注汞於内满，如此周插，如哉莲之状。 毕乃以如一分盖面，以合盖之定，固济合缝。 安入灰池合子上，常欲一寸半灰，灰上安四两火起头，增至十两火，昼夜。 第八日去余火，候冷开合子，采白琼条。 每一钱可点赤肉一两，为真换骨丹阳。 如以三二钱点作一两，愈妙。 不然独烹为银，亦可。 凡如此七次取物，至第八次，乃六日取物。 六日毕，次五日。 又四个四日，又三个三日，又二个二日，方至朝种暮收白雪，至此一钱，可糁汞三黄四初之妙，至此无不灵也。 日华子口诀 黄芽白雪金精第一黄芽捣碎，水飞淘。 随水过者，鼎器养为大药。 不随水过者，白砂销为宝，不可为药。 黄芽添汞产尘第二 用先内金分黄芽五两，入华池，添汞五两半，在火上结成砂子。 再挑量入鼎，封固二文武火养一日一夜。 再取出，浇汞五两，依前火候养之，取出皆成至宝。 黄芽修转玉田采宝第三 黄芽半斤，汞半斤，银末半斤，梼和如泥。 三味共入华池中，淬五十褊，取出，入炉鼎中，固济，养火，依前火候养之，取销成宝。 青霞子日：黄芽一两，可点赤杖子一两为至宝。 或将芽子五斤为母，五日一浇，五两采摘。

**Refining the Crucible’s Dimensions and the Dead Dragon Coiling Method (Continued)**

The upper crucible’s width is twice that of the lower, thus aligning with the **twenty-four qi** (*èrshí sì qì*). The upper crucible represents **Heaven**, the lower **Earth**; rising denotes **Yang**, descending denotes **Yin**. When **Yin-qi** seeks to ascend and **Yang-qi** seeks to descend, this reflects the **refining of Yin and Yang** (*yīnyáng táo yě*). The crucible’s width and length must neither be too large nor too small—**too broad disperses the qi, too narrow forces it to overflow**, thus failing to achieve the **balanced harmony of ascent and descent** (*shùn hé shēng jiàng*).

The upper crucible’s circumference is **twenty-four cùn**, while the lower is **three-tiered**, matching the crucible’s rim. The lower crucible’s length is **eight cùn**, its circumference **twelve cùn**, with a **three-tiered rim** to fit the upper crucible’s descent. **No deviation is permitted.**

This crucible lacks a base. Instead, **forge an iron rim to thicken it**, securing three **iron pegs** (*sān zhú*) as feet—**each as thick as a thumb, two and a half cùn high**. Then fashion the **Yin and Yang furnaces** (*yīnyáng èr lú*).

The **Yin furnace** is dug into the earth as a pit, burying a jar whose mouth matches the upper crucible. **Cover it with thick earth**, leveling it with the jar’s opening. **Shape the remaining soil into four walls**, resembling a **walled enclosure without ground** (*wú dì xiàng*). The **Yang furnace** is merely stacked flat on the earth.

When the **sixty-liǎng** of refined medicine is placed inside the crucible, **adjust with cinnabar paste** (*chì shí zhī*) to form a thin, cohesive mud. **Pierce with iron wire through the ears**, securing it tightly. **Refine as with Ling-Sha**, using **four-season fire** (*sìshí huǒ*) for **seven days and nights** to complete the process. **The three elements—water, fire, and medicine—correspond to Heaven, Earth, and Man** (*tiān dì rén sān cái*).

**Four-season fire** proceeds thus:
- **Spring fire** (*chūn huǒ*) seeks warmth,
- **Summer fire** (*xià huǒ*) seeks intensity,
- **Autumn fire** (*qiū huǒ*) seeks moderation,
- **Winter fire** (*dōng huǒ*) seeks subtlety.

This method is practiced on a **Child Day, Child Hour** (*zǐ rì zǐ shí*), placing the crucible atop the **three-footed stand**. **Insert the Yang furnace**, then stack charcoal beneath the crucible until its body is **one-third submerged**, using **gentle, slow-burning fire** (*huǎn wén huǒ*) to make the **inner qi intermingle** (*nèi xiāng jiāo gòu*), lasting **one and a half hours**.

Next, **apply fierce fire**, piling charcoal to **half the crucible’s height**, lasting **one and a half hours**. Then **intensify the flame**, raising the crucible’s body to **three-fifths its height**, lasting another **one and a half hours**. Finally, **gradually reduce the fire**, using **subtle heat** until the **inner medicine’s qi settles** (*nèi wēn wēn qì dìng*), lasting **one and a half hours**. At **midday**, remove the crucible and place it in the **Yin furnace**, seating its belly atop a **small jar’s mouth**, then **bury three-fifths of its body in ash**. **Drain the upper crucible’s moisture with cloth**, ensuring it is dry before placing it on the **crucible tray**. **Light one catty of fire**—**Spring fire**—inside. Let the **mercury within descend slowly**, lasting **one and a half hours**. **Stack charcoal and fan the flames**, gradually increasing the intensity for **one and a half hours**. Then **let the fire blaze fiercely**, from the **upper crucible tray to the ash**, until **one and a half hours** have passed. Afterward, **extinguish the upper fire**, then **gradually remove the lower fire**, using **subtle heat** until the **inner medicine’s qi stabilizes** (*nèi yào qì dìng*), lasting **one and a half hours**. By **midnight**, return the crucible to the **Yang furnace**, repeating the **ascent and descent** (*shèng jiàng*)—**now fully refined, yet still incomplete**—until **seven days and nights of fire** are fulfilled.

**Break the crucible**, extracting a small portion of **White Snow** (*bái xuě*). Place it in the **Qi furnace** (*qì lú*) to **dissolve into liquid** (*huài chéng zhī*), **without loss or waste** (*bù zhé bù hào*), completing the task.

If any **White Snow** is **slightly damaged or discolored**, refine another crucible using the same **ascent-descent method** for **seven days and nights**, then extract the **White Snow mercury** as **Great Treasure** (*dà bǎo*). Should the **elixir’s Dao** (*dānshì Dào*) be **leaked or exposed**, take this **Dead Dragon Coiling** (*sǐ lóng pán*) as **stillness** (*jìng*). Grind it in an **iron mortar** (*tiě xiàng*) until powdered. **Form a thin iron vessel** (*bó hézi*), placing **three parts of White Snow** inside, then **inserting a long hole** (*chā zhòng cháng kǒng*). **Fill it with mercury** until full, repeating this **circumferentially** (*zhōu chā*), resembling **a lotus pod** (*ruì lián zhī zhuàng*). **Cover the opening with one part**, securing the seam. **Place the vessel atop an ash pool**, keeping the ash **one and a half cùn deep**. **Light four liǎng of fire** to begin, increasing to **ten liǎng**—**day and night**. On the **eighth day**, extinguish the remaining fire. When cool, open the vessel and **harvest the White Snow crystals** (*bái qióng tiáo*). **Each one-catty portion** can **refine one liǎng of Ling-Sha** (*chì ròu*) into **True Elixir of Heavenly Transformation** (*zhēn huàn gǔ dān yáng*). If using **three to two catty portions** for one liǎng, the result is even more refined. Otherwise, **merely refining it yields silver**, which is also acceptable.

**In total, this process involves seven extractions.** By the **eighth extraction**, the method shifts to **six days of refining**. After six days, proceed to **five days**. Then **four sets of four days**, **three sets of three days**, **two sets of two days**, until finally reaching the **morning extraction and evening collection of White Snow** (*zhāo zhǒng mù shōu bái xuě*). At this point, **one liǎng can refine mercury into its highest purity** (*sǎn huáng sì chū zhī miào*), rendering it **infallibly effective** (*wú bù líng*).

**Master Day-Hua’s Oral Precepts:**
**First Refining: Yellow Sprout into Great Treasure**
Pound the **Yellow Sprout** (*huáng yá*) until shattered, then **water-fly and wash** (*shuǐ fēi táo*). Whatever **passes through the water** belongs to the **crucible’s vessel**, nurtured as **Great Medicine** (*dà yào*). What **does not pass** is **White Sand** (*bái shā*), melted into **Treasure** (*bǎo*), unfit for medicine.

**Second Refining: Yellow Sprout Produces Dust**
Take **five liǎng of inner gold** (*nèi jīn*) and **Yellow Sprout**, place in the **Hua Pool** (*huá chí*), adding **five and a half liǎng of mercury**. Refine it over fire until it **forms sand**. Extract and place it in the crucible, sealing it tightly. **Refine with two cycles of Wu and Wen fires** (*liǎng wén wǔ huǒ*), nurturing it **one day and one night**. Reextract and **pour five liǎng of mercury** over it, following the **previous fire cycles**. The result, when extracted, is **Great Treasure**.

**Third Refining: Cultivating Yellow Sprout into Jade Fields**
Take **half a catty of Yellow Sprout**, **half a catty of mercury**, and **half a catty of silver powder** (*yín mò*), mixing them uniformly into mud. **Combine the three essences** into the **Hua Pool**, quenching **fifty times** (*qìng wǔ shì*). Extract and place in the **furnace crucible**, securing it tightly. **Refine with fire**, following the **previous cycles**, until it **melts into Treasure**.

**Master Qing-Xia’s Saying:**
**One liǎng of Yellow Sprout** can **refine one liǎng of Ling-Sha** (*chì zhàng zǐ*) into **Great Treasure**. Alternatively, take **five catties of Sprout as the mother**, quenching it **once every five days**, extracting **five liǎng** each time.

chunks.original_text: 入生取熟，永不竭也。 明窗尘转修朱汞本源第四 明窗尘二两，入神室中，用颗块朱砂好者一两，入合子内，明窗尘上下铺盖，浇汞一两，同固济，入灰池养中，养四十九日。 取出开看，皆成紫金粉，灶之成宝，上色真金明窗尘，是紫粉不变药者是也。 若人服食，取研如粉，枣肉丸如蒙豆大，空心，井花水下一粒，安魂定魄，去病延年。 有卒经一七不坏者，用朱砂半钱，冷水倾入死人口内，片时自活。 其明窗尘，用楮汁丸如麻豆大，空心，下一粒，至二粒，延年，极有神效焉。 明窗尘修二气法第五 明窗尘二两，入鼎内。 生硫黄一两，汞一两，二味一处细研，入鼎中，明窗尘铺盖上下，固济，入炉，养火五日。 取看皆紫金色，然后一处细研，每入生硫黄五钱，一处研之，楮汁丸如蒙豆大，一丸可糁汞一斤成宝。 明窗尘修河车第六 明窗尘五两，入神室中，乃大神室也。 为用汞五两，如莲子哉尘内，固济，入炉，依前火养七日。 开看皆作其芽，飞於鼎上，紫河车粉，芽子销之成真宝。 紫河车变金液第七 紫河车五两重为末，子醋和成膏，捏作合子，候乾，将汞在内，入神室内，固济，养火七日。 开看皆成丹砂汞，销之成真宝。 紫河车修黄举第八 紫河车一两，辰砂一两，细研如粉，入神室中，固济，灰池，养火四十九日。 取出细研，楮汁丸如胡麻子大，空心，用无灰酒下一粒。 此丹能返魂起死，服之十日，三尸自离。 青虚子曰：人卒亡经七日不坏，用此丹半钱，冷水调入口内，随时自活回生。 黄举伏雄黄变质第九 黄举一两，辰砂一两，汞一两，雄黄五钱，一处同研细，入神室中，养火七日足。 取出细研，枣肉丸如蒙豆大，每日空心，井花水下一粒。 如阳衰气绝，精神恍惚，服之固阳生力，刚强倍加，返老还童，回生起死。 内臣服之，再童颜，功难比。 汞一斤入跳内，丹二粒糁之成宝。 雄黄点化第十 将前黄举丸子，入神室内。 再用黄举末一两，上下铺盖固济，依前火候，养百日足，取出丹一丸，可点铁一斤作真金。 神验不可议论，至此通灵变化也。 紫河车糁汞成宝第十一 将黄举并芽一处，入辰砂四两，神室中铺盖固济，依前火养三十五日足，取出。 ．将朱砂为末，楮汁为丸，如蒙豆大，每一粒糁汞十两，成至宝。 黄举修成紫河车第十二 将粉霜一两，铺盖入炉，养三七日取出。 每粒糁汞十两为宝，将此物别有变化。 紫金丹修制五金第十三 河车粉一两，入神室中，依前固济，养火一年，其火力与大．药伺。 楮汁丸如蒙豆大，一粒点五金为至宝。 紫金神化法第十四 将前紫河车粉，再入神室固济，养一年取。 枣肉丸如麻豆大，入神室固济，四十九日取出。 用物包袅，束流水浸四十九日，取出。 斋戒沐浴，空心，无灰酒下一粒，别有灵验。 变紫金丹第十五 将此金河车四两，或半斤，入金神室中。 将成芽子一两，用紫河车上下铺盖封固，养一年取出，方分五丹。 至宝遇金丹第十六 依前匮养火一年，开炉，斋戒沐浴，醮谢天地，方开鼎收取诸丹。 若见鼎上凝结，如真红色者，名曰龙虎大还丹。 服之百日，冲升长生不死，云游紫府，鸡犬服之，化为龙凤。 其合内四面金花，如鱼鳞片相似，名日神符白雪丹。

**Fourth Refining: Cultivating the Essence of Ming-Chuang Dust into the Original Source of Vermilion and Mercury**
Take **two liǎng of Ming-Chuang dust** (*míng chuāng chén*), placing it in the **Divine Chamber**. Use **high-quality cinnabar lumps** (*zhu shān kē kuài*) of **one liǎng**, enclosing them within the **fusion vessel**. Spread the **Ming-Chuang dust** above and below, then pour **one liǎng of mercury** over it, securing it tightly. Place it in the **ash pool** for refining, nurturing it for **forty-nine days**.

When opened, all becomes **violet gold powder** (*zǐ jīn fěn*). Smelt it into **Treasure**, and its hue will match **true gold**—this is the **unchangeable violet powder elixir**.

If ingested, grind it finely into powder, form **dates-flesh pills** (*zǎo ròu wán*) the size of **mung beans** (*méng dòu*), and swallow **one grain** with an empty stomach using **well-bloom water** (*jǐng huā shuǐ*). It will **settle the spirit and stabilize the soul** (*àn hún dìng pò*), dispel illness, and prolong life. There are also **posthumous prescriptions** (*cù jīng*) that remain unspoiled for **seven days**—use **half a qián of cinnabar**, mix with cold water, and pour into the mouth of the deceased. They will revive in **mere moments**.

Its **Ming-Chuang dust** may be formed into **pills with ramie juice** (*chǔ zhī wán*), the size of **sesame seeds** (*má dòu*), with **one to two grains** swallowed to prolong life, exhibiting **extraordinary spiritual efficacy**.

**Fifth Refining: Cultivating Ming-Chuang Dust with the Two Qi Method**
Take **two liǎng of Ming-Chuang dust**, placing it in the **crucible**. Use **one liǎng of raw sulfur** (*shuāi huáng*) and **one liǎng of mercury**, grinding both finely together, then layering them within the crucible above and below the **Ming-Chuang dust**, securing it tightly. Place it in the **furnace** and refine with fire for **five days**.

When opened, all will appear **violet gold** in color. Grind it finely again, then add **five qián of raw sulfur** each time, grinding uniformly. Form **pills with ramie juice** the size of **mung beans**, and **one pill** can **coat one catty of mercury** to produce **Treasure**.

**Sixth Refining: Cultivating Ming-Chuang Dust into the River Chariot**
Take **five liǎng of Ming-Chuang dust**, placing it in the **Divine Chamber**—this is the **Great Divine Chamber**. Use **five liǎng of mercury**, layering it like **lotus seeds** within the **dust**, securing it tightly. Place it in the **furnace** and refine with fire following the **previous cycles** for **seven days**.

When opened, all will sprout, ascending like **sprouts** upon the crucible, forming **violet River Chariot powder** (*zǐ hé chē fěn*). Smelt the **sprouts** into **true Treasure**.

**Seventh Refining: Transforming the River Chariot into Violet Gold Elixir**
Take **five liǎng of violet River Chariot powder**, grind it into fine powder, mix with **vinegar** (*zǐ cù*) to form a paste, and knead it into a **fusion vessel**. Once dry, place **mercury** inside, then enclose it in the **Divine Chamber**, securing it tightly. Refine with fire for **seven days**.

When opened, all will become **vermilion, cinnabar, and mercury** (*dān shā gǒng*). Smelt it into **true Treasure**.

**Eighth Refining: Cultivating the River Chariot into Yellow Sprout**
Take **one liǎng of violet River Chariot** and **one liǎng of realgar** (*chén shā*), grinding both finely into powder. Place it in the **Divine Chamber**, secure it tightly, and refine in the **ash pool** for **forty-nine days**.

When extracted, grind it finely again. Form **pills with ramie juice** the size of **hemp seeds** (*hú má zǐ*), with an empty core, and swallow **one grain** with **unsooted wine** (*wú huī jiǔ*). This **elixir** can **restore the soul and revive the dead** (*fǎn hún qǐ sǐ*). Ingesting it for **ten days** will cause the **Three Corpses** (*sān shī*) to depart.

**Master Qing-Xū’s Saying:**
If a person dies and their body remains unspoiled for **seven days**, use **half a qián of this elixir**, mix with cold water, and pour into their mouth. They will revive and return to life at any time.

**Ninth Refining: Subduing Realgar with Male Sulfur to Transform Its Nature**
Take **one liǎng of Yellow Sprout**, **one liǎng of realgar**, **one liǎng of mercury**, and **five qián of male sulfur** (*xióng huáng*), grinding them all finely together. Place it in the **Divine Chamber** and refine with fire for **seven days**—this is sufficient.

When extracted, grind it finely again. Form **dates-flesh pills** the size of **mung beans**, and swallow **one grain daily** with an empty stomach using **well-bloom water**. If taken when **yang vitality is declining** (*yáng shuāi*) or **life force is exhausted** (*qì jué*), with **spirit wandering and confused** (*jīng shén huǎng hu*), ingesting it will **stabilize and restore yang vitality** (*gù yáng shēng lì*), **doubling strength and vigor** (*gāng jiàng bèi jiā*), **reverting aging to youth** (*fǎn lǎo huán tóng*), and **reviving the dying** (*huí shēng qǐ sǐ*).

If taken by **inner attendants** (*nèi chén*), it will **renew their youthful complexion** (*zài tóng yán*), with effects **unmatched in efficacy**.

**Mercury’s Transformation: The Tenth Method**
Place **one catty of mercury** in the **leaping vessel** (*tiào nài*), and **two grains of elixir** can **coat it** to produce **Treasure**.

**Eleventh Refining: The Male Sulfur Method of Transformation**
Take the **previously prepared Yellow Sprout pills**, placing them in the **Divine Chamber**. Use **one liǎng of Yellow Sprout powder** to layer above and below, securing it tightly. Refine with fire following the **previous cycles** for **one hundred days**—this is sufficient. When opened, **one grain of elixir** can **coat one catty of iron** to transform it into **true gold**.

**Dao/Way’s Verification is Beyond Debate**—by now, **spiritual transformations** (*líng biàn huà*) are complete.

**Twelfth Refining: Coating Mercury with Violet River Chariot to Produce Treasure**
Combine the **Yellow Sprout** and the **River Chariot sprouts** uniformly, then add **four liǎng of realgar**. Layer and secure them in the **Divine Chamber**, refining with fire following the **previous cycles** for **thirty-five days**—this is sufficient. When extracted, grind the **cinnabar** into powder and form **pills with ramie juice** the size of **mung beans**. Each **grain** can **coat ten liǎng of mercury** to produce **Great Treasure**.

**Thirteenth Refining: Cultivating the Violet River Chariot into Yellow Sprout**
Take **one liǎng of powdered frost** (*fěn shuāng*), layering and securing it in the **furnace**, refining for **twenty-one days** (*sān qī rì*). When extracted, each **grain** can **coat ten liǎng of mercury** to produce **Treasure**. This substance has **other transformations**.

**Fourteenth Refining: The Violet Gold Elixir’s Method of Subduing the Five Metals**
Take **one liǎng of River Chariot powder**, placing it in the **Divine Chamber** and securing it tightly as before. Refine with fire for **one year**, adjusting the **fire’s intensity** (*huǒ lì*) like the **Great Elixir**.

Form **pills with ramie juice** the size of **mung beans**, and **one grain** can **coat the five metals** to produce **Great Treasure**.

**Fifteenth Refining: The Dao/Way’s Method of Violet Gold Transformation**
Take the **previously prepared violet River Chariot powder**, place it in the **Divine Chamber**, and secure it tightly. Refine with fire for **one year**, then extract. Form **dates-flesh pills** the size of **hemp seeds**, placing them in the **Divine Chamber** and securing it tightly for **forty-nine days** before extraction.

Wrap the substance and immerse it in **flowing water** for **forty-nine days**, then extract. Observe **ritual purity** (*zhāi jiè*), bathe, and swallow **one grain** with an empty stomach using **unsooted wine**. It exhibits **other spiritual efficacies**.

**Sixteenth Refining: Transforming into Violet Gold Elixir**
Take **four liǎng (or half a catty)** of this **golden River Chariot** (*jīn hé chē*), placing it in the **Golden Divine Chamber**. Use **one liǎng of sprouts**, layering the **violet River Chariot** above and below to secure and seal it. Refine with fire for **one year**, then extract, dividing it into **five elixirs**.

If **Great Treasure** encounters **golden elixir** (*jīn dān*), refine with fire following the **previous cycles** for **one year**. Upon opening the **furnace**, observe **ritual purity**, bathe, and **offer thanks to Heaven and Earth** (*zhòu xiè tiān dì*). Only then open the **crucible** to collect the **various elixirs**.

If **congealed formations** (*níng jié*) are seen on the **crucible**, resembling **true vermilion**, it is called the **Dragon-Tiger Great Reversion Elixir** (*Lóng Hǔ Dà Huán Dān*). Ingesting it for **one hundred days** will **cleanse and elevate one to immortality** (*chōng shēng cháng shēng bù sǐ*), allowing **cloud-soaring in the Violet Palace** (*yún yóu zǐ fǔ*). Even **chickens and dogs** that consume it will **transform into dragons and phoenixes**.

Within the **fusion vessel**, there are **golden flowers** on all four sides, resembling **fish scales** (*yú lín piàn*), called the **Divine Symbol White Snow Elixir** (*Shén Fú Bái Xuě Dān*).

chunks.original_text: 如四畔淡红色者，名日紫极丹。 紫色不变诸色，又名日紫金丹。 如鼎畔皆花，金色光灿，名金液小还丹。 已上诸丹，楮汁丸如麻子大，候乾以物包，以东流水浸百日。 取井花水，下一粒，服丹四两，为一剂。 此丹仍精心详密，自觉神验。 服千日，骨体五脏皆金色。 世上金石草木丹皆不清，此丹无毒，入水入火，皆不能近，诸邪远离，亦为地仙也。 又十六变 黄芽见宝第一 黄芽令碎，水淘之，浮者养之为药，水内砂子销为宝，号曰白金。 黄芽抽添产药第二 取水－内砂子五两，添汞华池，结成垒，入铁合子固济，养三日，常用火一两，又日五两，至一斤。 入神室，养九转。 点五金服之，长生，号赤石丹。 赤石丹种玉田第三 此名入仙玉本，又名大涌泉。 取赤石丹砂一两，养汞十两，醋为末，水银十两，同搅为泥，然后入华池，淬十褊。 更以汞十两，却入铁合中，上用砂石盖之，固济。 常用火五两，灰池中养七日满。 再入汞三两，养七日，生白笑，取三两，入三两。 入生取咽，灶为宝，永不尽，金壳之术固也。 转为四神丹又取明窗尘第四 四神丹一两，舶上硫黄半两，汞三两，同研为粉，入湖南瓶子，内灰池，养三七日，半两至十两，即住。 二十一日取出，研二千褊。 养至一年，渐化轻尘，水不能溺，火不能焚。 日当午，抛少许於虚空，化为白云，渐渐升天，莫测高深也。 明窗尘转修汞第五 明窗尘五两，米醋和为膏，乾入汞合中固济，文武火养一伏时，出为宝，可作器，辨诸毒。 明窗伏不夺元色伏朱砂法第六 取明窗尘，上下铺盖朱砂，文武火养一伏时，成。 枣肉丸，服之安魂定魄。 人卒死经七日，用伏火朱砂半钱，冷水调，入口即活，能返魂。 其明窗尘伏火朱砂，养之一年，变化与大丹同，但不能升腾。 明窗尘点铜化银第七 取砒为粉，明清园之，用明窗尘上下铺盖，养一伏时，每两点杖子一斤为宝矣。 修黄举第八又名紫河车 黄举一十两，或一斤，修如大药法，养十月，如紫金粉也。 紫河车添汞第九 紫河车一两，汞一斤，入华池，淬三褊，汞自为白霜。 入合固济，养七日，即为黄金。 取出，添汞，依此法，是人种金，乃壳子术也。 紫河车雄黄木第十 河车粉要成块，雄黄不拘多少，用粉於合子中，上下盖之固济，灰池养七日，成伏火雄黄。 每一两为粉，生龙脑一钱，楮汁丸为篆豆大，空心，无灰酒下三粒。 伏火雄黄乾汞第十一 汞十两，伏火雄黄末半两，姚内糁汞上，湿纸茶盏盖之令恰好，以文武火一伏时，渐烧跳子通红，即成宝也。 紫河车修紫丹第十二 紫河车四两，汞八两，雄黄四两，入铁合子中固济，灰池养火四十九日，如养一年，如紫磨黄金色。 楮汁丸如麻豆大，每粒制汞一斤为至宝。 紫金还丹乾汞成金第十三 汞一斤，丹一丸，同入跳子内盖之，灰池中慢火养一伏时，偶成黄色，灶之为宝。 紫金还丹变铁成金第十四 生铁一斤，烟为水紫金。 还丹一粒，入锅点之，成上色金也。 紫金还丹点铜成金第十五 铜一斤，烟为水。 丹一丸，入锅中点之，成上色金也。 服紫金还丹第十六、 每日空心，清酒下三丸。 服至千粒，一切毒蛇猛兽，精魅邪神，皆不能害。 非世上金石草木之比。 服之千日，五脏骨髓皆金色，长生不死，陆地神仙，升腾紫府。

If the four sides are of a pale red hue, it is called the **Purple Extremity Elixir** (*Zǐ Jí Dān*). Since purple does not change with other colors, it is also called the **Purple-Gold Elixir** (*Zǐ Jīn Dān*). If the crucible’s edges are entirely adorned with golden flowers, radiant and dazzling, it is called the **Golden Elixir of the Minor Reversion** (*Jīn Yè Xiǎo Huán Dān*).

As for the above elixirs, roll them into pills with mulberry bark juice the size of hemp seeds, let them dry, wrap them, and soak them in flowing eastern water for one hundred days. Take a drop of well-water, place one grain inside, and take four *liang* of the elixir as one dose. This elixir must be refined with utmost care and precision—its divine efficacy is self-evident. After a thousand days of ingestion, one’s bones, body, and five viscera will all turn golden. All the elixirs of gold, stone, herbs, and wood in the world are impure, but this elixir is non-toxic. Neither water nor fire can harm it; all malevolent forces keep their distance, and it grants the status of an **Earthly Immortal**.

**Sixteen Transformations**
**Yellow Sprout Encounters Treasure (First)**
Crush the yellow sprout and wash it in water. The floating portion is cultivated as medicine; the sand within the water dissolves into treasure, called **White Gold**. **Yellow Sprout Extracts and Produces Medicine (Second)**
Take five *liang* of the sand from the water, add it to the mercury pool, and let it solidify into a mound. Place it in an iron vessel and seal it tightly. Nurture it for three days, then gradually increase the fire from two *liang* to five *liang* daily, until it reaches one *jin*. Place it in the **Divine Chamber** and refine it through nine cycles. When ingested with the five metals, it grants immortality—known as the **Red Stone Elixir** (*Chì Shí Dān*).

**Red Stone Elixir Seeds the Jade Field (Third)**
This is called the **Immortal Jade Root** or the **Great Gushing Spring**. Take one *liang* of red cinnabar, refine ten *liang* of mercury, grind it into powder with vinegar, and mix it with ten *liang* of quicksilver, stirring into a paste. Then place it in the mercury pool and temper it ten times. Again, add ten *liang* of mercury into an iron vessel, cover it with sand and stone, and seal it tightly. Nurture it in an ash pool with five *liang* of fire for seven days until full. Add another three *liang* of mercury, nurture for seven more days until it produces white laughter—take three *liang* of this and add it to three more *liang*. When ingested, it becomes a **Cauldron Treasure**, inexhaustible, a technique of the **Golden Shell**.

**Transformed into the Four Divine Elixirs (Fourth: Taking Clear Window Dust)**
Take one *liang* of the **Four Divine Elixir**, half a *liang* of sulfur from the ship, and three *liang* of mercury, grinding them into powder. Place them in a bottle from Hunan, set within an ash pool, and nurture for twenty-one days, increasing from half a *liang* to ten *liang*, then cease. After twenty-one days, remove and grind it two thousand times. After a year of refinement, it gradually transforms into light dust—water cannot drown it, fire cannot burn it. At noon, scatter a small amount into the empty sky, and it will turn into white clouds, ascending to heaven with unfathomable depth.

**Refining Mercury with Clear Window Dust (Fifth)**
Take five *liang* of **Clear Window Dust**, mix it with rice vinegar into a paste, dry it, and place it in a mercury vessel, sealing it tightly. Refine it with both gentle and fierce fires for one *fu* period, and it becomes treasure—usable as an instrument and capable of distinguishing all poisons.

**Clear Window Dust Preserves Its Original Color (Sixth: Method of Refining Cinnabar)**
Take **Clear Window Dust**, layer cinnabar above and below, and refine it with both gentle and fierce fires for one *fu* period. Form it into pills with date-flesh juice. Ingesting them calms the soul and steadies the spirit. If a person dies and has been deceased for seven days, use half a *qian* of refined cinnabar with cold water, and place it in their mouth—they will revive, their soul returned. If **Clear Window Dust** and refined cinnabar are nurtured for a year, their transformations match those of the Great Elixir, though they cannot ascend.

**Clear Window Dust Transforms Copper into Silver (Seventh)**
Take arsenic and grind it into powder. Purify it in a clear garden, then layer **Clear Window Dust** above and below, and refine it for one *fu* period. For every *liang* of powder, add one *jin* of the rod to make treasure.

**Refining Yellow Lead (Eighth, also called Purple River Carriage)**
Take ten *liang* (or one *jin*) of yellow lead and refine it like a great medicine for ten months, until it becomes purple-gold powder.

**Purple River Carriage Adds Mercury (Ninth)**
Take one *liang* of **Purple River Carriage** and one *jin* of mercury, place them in the mercury pool, and temper them three times. The mercury will naturally form white frost. Seal it in a vessel and nurture for seven days—it will become yellow gold. Remove it, add more mercury, and follow this method repeatedly. This is the **Human Seed Gold**, a technique of the **Shell Art**.

**Purple River Carriage and Realgar Wood (Tenth)**
When the **Purple River Carriage** powder forms a block, take an unrestricted amount of realgar, place the powder in a vessel, and layer it above and below, sealing it tightly. Nurture it in an ash pool for seven days to produce **Refined Realgar**. For every *liang* of powder, add one *qian* of bornite resin, roll it into pills with mulberry bark juice the size of broad beans, and take three with empty stomachs, using unslaked wine.

**Refined Realgar and Dry Mercury (Eleventh)**
Take ten *liang* of mercury and half a *liang* of refined realgar powder. Sprinkle the mercury inside, cover it with damp paper in a tea cup, and seal it tightly. Refine it with both gentle and fierce fires for one *fu* period, gradually heating until the crucible glows red—it will then become treasure.

**Purple River Carriage Refines the Purple Elixir (Twelfth)**
Take four *liang* of **Purple River Carriage**, eight *liang* of mercury, and four *liang* of realgar, place them in an iron vessel, and seal it tightly. Nurture it in an ash pool for forty-nine days—equivalent to a year of refinement—until it turns the color of polished yellow gold. Roll it into pills with mulberry bark juice the size of hemp seeds. Each grain can refine one *jin* of mercury into the ultimate treasure.

**Purple-Gold Reversion Elixir Transforms Dry Mercury into Gold (Thirteenth)**
Take one *jin* of mercury and one pill of the elixir, place them together in a crucible, and refine them slowly in an ash pool with gentle fire for one *fu* period. If it turns yellow, it becomes treasure from the furnace.

**Purple-Gold Reversion Elixir Transforms Iron into Gold (Fourteenth)**
Take one *jin* of raw iron and temper it into **Water Purple-Gold**. Place one grain of the elixir in a pot and apply it—it will become superior gold.

**Purple-Gold Reversion Elixir Transforms Copper into Gold (Fifteenth)**
Take one *jin* of copper and temper it into water. Place one grain of the elixir in a pot and apply it—it will become superior gold.

**Ingesting the Purple-Gold Reversion Elixir (Sixteenth)**
Take three pills with an empty stomach daily, using clear wine. After ingesting a thousand pills, all venomous snakes, fierce beasts, malevolent spirits, and evil deities will be powerless to harm you. It surpasses all worldly elixirs of gold, stone, herbs, and wood. After a thousand days of ingestion, one’s five viscera, bones, and marrow will all turn golden, granting immortality and eternal life as a **Land-Bound Immortal**, ascending to the Violet Palace.

chunks.original_text: 太微帝君长生保命丹 九还七返寒林第一 制真铅法：用山泽银，入甘锅内，缎成汁，作粟米珠。 养朱砂法，用透明朱砂一两半，悬胎煮一伏时，煮药用硼砂、胆矾、白矾各二钱，青盐半两。 右同用为末，苦酒内煮了沐浴。 沐浴用羌花、远志、川椒各三钱，水煮半日取出，火上焙乾，浓研松煤墨於盏内，滚之令黑。 却用贴身药，用炼过蜜滚上贴身矾石末，入合时，先用野苎根、羌花、远志、盐四味，调捣成膏，涂合内，然后下铅末，如我莲状，重重盖之，以荷叶隔定，缎过盐末盖头，固济，入灰池，养火。 三两火养三日，三两半火养三日，四两火养一日。 取出，火上试之成汁。 如尚有未伏，再养之候伏。 却取出，再以朱砂一两半入匮养，并依前法火候，亦如七日取出，共得砂三两。 就将此砂三两为匮，再用生朱砂二两半，依前法煮炼，入头转三两伏火。 朱砂匮内养之，不用野苎根护匮，但用砂盖头填实封固也。 入灰池，养火。 二两火养二日，三两火养三日，取出三斤，熟火毁之，候冷取出，其色赤白，细研，亦添入匮，养第三转用。 第三转增砂成宝质法 将此前五两砂，研细为匮。 再以朱砂三两，并依前法制度贴身，亦如火候。 如第二转火候出，其色白而不改。 此第三转同前，共得八两作匮，又加药养通灵，为九转之法。 第四转除胎气不增添法 将前八两朱砂，同研入合，以云母石片盖之，滑石末填实固济，入灰缸中养火，以三两火养三日，取出去滑石。 第五转还土体变黄色能生物 将第四转朱砂，再入合，亦用云母石片盖了。 以好雄黄二两，研为细末，又盖。 依前火三两养三日，色反黄如土色也。 其雄黄收起别用。 第六转不用盖头仙基之法 五转之中见接上 土体但以草药固之，六九者还质也。 以阳火缎之，而作灰也。 将前砂入合，不以云母石盖之，但用养麦秆灰拌盖之，以火三两养三日。 第七转称七返 朱砂至七转，色返红，复为母砂，故日还丹。 至此灵变出也。 初产时色碧，像母也。 不用铅，则五黄三白变化之中，须候同药。 及至七返九还之数，却以元产之铅为外固，此乃返本还元之道也。 凡万物返归本元，乃长生变化也。 自此还元质，可以死汞为七转也。 七转将前朱砂，再研入合，盖之。 却以第一转铅盖之，以火三两养三日，取出，其色返红，能变化黄白六两。 母到不用七返，既定八转，可以生物。 将此七返朱砂为匮，养三七母砂二两，分作四块固济，养之，以二两火养三日，四两养一日。 如此养三次了，再用养二分母砂，火候如前，再养九一。 母砂并养三次，坏之成宝。 却将七返朱砂匮末二停为底，入砂合子，於内作坑子四个，每个入汞半两，上却以一停匮末盖之，下火二两，养三日，取出。 再作坑子，依前众汞二两，并依前法。 右如此浇三十次之后，浇二两汞倒下，二两火养之一宿，到此方通灵也，方入八转之妙。 第八转离母造化入合浇汞玄中也用生朱砂四两，金箔袅之，入丹合内，用火养之，此一转通在第一变内说。 第九转亦名九还丹 取出所养朱砂，别用一合浇养之，此通十六变内说其详细。 铅汞甲庚至宝集成卷之三竟 铅汞甲庚至宝集成卷之四
